docs.abstract: Elizabeth M Whelan letter on attempts to ban junk foods from schools explains problem of definition; points out that extra calories, from any source, are what contribute to obesity
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Attempts to ban ''junk food'' from schools are not the answer to childhood obesity (front page, May 20). How will school officials define junk foods? A serving of potato chips and half an avocado each has about 15 grams of fat and 160 calories. Will schools ban avocados?

docs.abstract: Dr Caroline Poplin letter on Devin Friedman's May 5 article holds many of patient visits that burden doctors are unnecessary
docs.lead_paragraph: As a primary-care physician, I believe that the doctor's dilemma described in Friedman's article may be even more complicated than your writer suggests. And those of us who are patients and insurance beneficiaries are implicated also. Let's take another look at Jim Levine's day. Eight sore throats: these are almost always viral. The normal immune system can easily handle these viruses, and the patient will feel better in a week. Young, healthy, asymptomatic Americans do not need annual physicals; at most, they need a blood-pressure check (high blood pressure has no symptoms) and, in their 30's, a cholesterol test. Young people with no symptoms and no risk factors for heart disease need no more than one EKG, for baseline. Obesity is a major health problem in the country, but Weight Watchers and the public health system can address it more effectively and efficiently than I can. In other words, many of Levine's patients need not have visited the doctor at all that day. And with those patients off his schedule, there would have been more time for people who need his care. However, his patients had insurance; he needs to support a family; and it is safer to see healthy patients with trivial complaints, especially if time is short. Caroline Poplin, M.D. Bethesda, Md.

docs.abstract: Susan Tolchin, top spokeswoman for Westchester County government, is appointed chief adviser to County Executive Andrew Spano; will supervise new emergency management for evacuating area around Indian Point nuclear power plant and will remain communications director (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE top spokeswoman for Westchester County government, Susan Tolchin, has been appointed chief adviser to the county executive and, among other duties, will supervise a new emergency management plan for evacuating the area surrounding the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Buchanan. Ms. Tolchin's appointment fills a void created when the county's top emergency preparedness official, Christopher Kozlow, was fired on May 16. But Ms. Tolchin said her promotion was not connected to Mr. Kozlow's departure.

docs.abstract: Editorial notes efforts under way in several states to restrict availability of so-called junk foods in public schools; says other half of overweight problem, lack of physical activity, is not helped when schools cut back on gym classes
docs.lead_paragraph: The eve of a long holiday weekend may not be the most propitious time to rail against junk food, but we feel duty bound to note that obesity was back in the spotlight this month as a major public health problem. A Senate committee held hearings this week on a bill designed to combat the obesity epidemic in this country, where some 60 percent of all American adults are either overweight or obese. And the annual meeting of the World Health Organization heard reports of an alarming increase in overweight children in developing countries, some of which are fast closing the gap with the traditionally fatter industrialized nations. A favorite villain in most analyses of the global girth problem is the so-called junk foods -- the sodas, chips and candy bars that tend to be high in calories and low in nutritional value. That is why efforts are under way in several states to restrict the availability of junk food in the public schools, as chronicled by Timothy Egan in Monday's Times. But it is an uphill battle given the lobbying might of the food industry and the financial interests of school districts that profit from vending machine sales on their premises.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-18 Suicide Bomb Near Tel Aviv Kills 2 Israelis and Hurts 27 A suicide bomber blew himself up at a park gazebo in Rishon Le Zion, killing himself, at least 2 Israelis and injuring 27 people. It was the third suicide bombing in four days in Israel and the second in barely two weeks in Rishon le Zion, southeast of Tel Aviv. Earlier, Israeli forces killed a well-known Palestinian militant and two of his comrades near Nablus. A1 Prime Minister Ariel Sharon won legislative approval for an emergency economic package. A12
